poem:
Euston Station Meditation  

Why scramble at dawn for the chance  
to extract a bleak reward—  
the worm that's hidden  
deep in London's veins?  
Euston's corridors echo with promise,  
a place we all seem to visit  
before our tickets to elsewhere.  
Think of it as a practice space,  
a rehearsal room for leaving.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why be an early bird, if you don’t want worms? | David Mitchell Good news for regular users of Euston station in London! One day they will die. Then they won’t have to go to Euston station ever again. Most Observer readers have probably been to Euston station at some point in their lives but I do advise any of you who haven’t to stick that fact on the list the next time you count". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Why be an early bird, if you don’t want worms? | David Mitchell Good news for regular users of Euston station in London! One day they will die.
